unnormalised: Okay, so someone just asked, "What's the weirdest address you've ever seen?" Bhai, let me tell you about trying to find Priya Sharma's place in Bangalore last year. It was an adventure straight out of a Bollywood comedy.
normalised: Okay, so someone just asked, "What's the weirdest address you've ever seen?" Bhai, let me tell you about trying to find Priya Sharma's place in Bangalore last year. It was an adventure straight out of a Bollywood comedy.

unnormalised: The address, as she texted it, was something like "Opposite that big banyan tree, near the old temple, behind the CCD, kinda next to the blue gate, #420, 1st floor, Thindlu, Bangalore, 560097." CCD? Which one?! Bangalore has more Coffee Day outlets than auto-rickshaws have meters! And "kinda next to" isn't exactly GPS-friendly.
normalised: The address, as she texted it, was something like "Opposite that big banyan tree, near the old temple, behind the C-C-D, kinda next to the blue gate, hash four hundred and twenty, first floor, Thindlu, Bangalore, five six zero zero nine seven." C-C-D? Which one?! Bangalore has more Coffee Day outlets than auto-rickshaws have meters! And "kinda next to" isn't exactly G-P-S-friendly.

unnormalised: So, I'm driving around Thindlu, which by the way, feels like a village swallowed by a city. First, I find a banyan tree, but there are *three* temples nearby. I ask a chaiwala. He says, "Oh, that tree? Go straight, take a left at the mithai shop, then ask again." Classic Indian directions.
normalised: So, I'm driving around Thindlu, which by the way, feels like a village swallowed by a city. First, I find a banyan tree, but there are three temples nearby. I ask a chaiwala. He says, "Oh, that tree? Go straight, take a left at the mithai shop, then ask again." Classic Indian directions.

unnormalised: After about 45 minutes of circling and getting increasingly hangry, I finally spot a blue gate. And lo and behold, a number 420! Turns out, it was technically "#420/A", but who's counting, right? 1st floor, of course, meant climbing some rickety stairs that looked like they hadn't been inspected since 1947. But hey, at least the chai at Priya's was worth the hassle... maybe.
normalised: After about forty five minutes of circling and getting increasingly hangry, I finally spot a blue gate. And lo and behold, a number four hundred and twenty! Turns out, it was technically "hash four hundred and twenty slash A", but who's counting, right? First floor, of course, meant climbing some rickety stairs that looked like they hadn't been inspected since one thousand nine hundred and forty seven. But hey, at least the chai at Priya's was worth the hassle... maybe.
